cons: I worked in this department prior to becoming an RN, so I have a decent amount of experience although I’ve only been an RN for a year. Pay is lower than other hospitals in the area. I’m now on my 3rd orientee, but making the same as the new grads that I’m training that have no experience and an associates degree.

pros: Supportive Work Environment: Norton fosters a supportive and nurturing work environment for its nursing staff. job_title: Emergency Medical Technician (EMT) in Louisville, KY
pros: Less stressful than 911 Higher pay than 911 EMS New equipment, resources are well provided Laid back coworkers, base is equipped with a kitchen for lunch breaks PRN gets paid well, an EMT gets around $22/hour for PRN and every shift you pick up you can get an extra $8/hour on top of it. The hospital itself is a great place to work with most employees
cons: Was put on administrative leave for reporting a coworker attacking a patient. Had to file a retaliation complaint to come back to work, DOL said Norton Healthcare is notorious for retaliation. Medicare fraud is everywhere, management expects you to participate or you are refusing runs and will be terminated. Management only communicates for information, there is no dialogue with management. Sexual harassment occurs in the workplace, management is aware of it and after multiple complaints by multiple coworkers has done nothing to correct it. Homophobia occurs in our department, with homophobic slurs being repeated by multiple coworkers, same non-response from management. Management is really hands off, if you work on the weekend you will never see your manager. Mandatory monthly meetings and quarterly trainings. You have to attend in person of will receive an attendance point. Pay is lower than competitors. Department is terribly understaffed, meaning you don’t have an incentive to work full time, because you show up for your shift at $19/hour while the PRN EMT is making $30/hour doing the same job because they picked up the open shift last minute. Transport recently started taking patients back home including the dangerous parts of town 24 hours a day. On the weekends there will only be 2 ambulances, they will send one out of town so the ALS ambulance will do all the runs. Management plays favoritism, rules apply for some and not for others. Some workers will be allowed to just sit at base if they don’t want to work with someone, and others will be sent home with a coaching on their employee record. Norton continually offers retention plans like tuition reimbursement, but our department is exempt from them. I receive 1-2 communications from management every day for things ranging from requests for additional staffing to notices about policy changes and trainings. This occurs on my days off, and am held accountable for having read them. There is no system for checking these when you come back into work,

job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician in Louisville, KY
pros:
The inpatient pharmacy team is the most diverse and positive that I have ever worked with. Tech supervisors were realistic with their expectations, understanding of work-life balance, and never guilted me when I couldn't pick up a shift. The pharmacists acted like part of the team, and helped out when tech staffing was low.

Sterile compounding experience was not required, and the team was happy to train me.
cons:
Recruitment is very mismanaged: the company struggled to get job offers accepted, and retain new hires. According to department leadership, this was due in part to the fact that applicants were not offered positions at other locations if they were not needed at the specific location they applied to.

Compensation was not adequate for the amount of work required. In light of a staffing shortage, all shifts needed to adjust their schedules and stay late frequently in order to complete their work. There was no incentive to the team to compensate for the additional workload, except for picking up an entire additional shift. Despite the increasing staff shortage, the shift pickup bonus was actually reduced. The company-issued appreciation gifts were near-unanimously ridiculed. Examples include a picnic blanket in late-fall, a bluetooth speaker, and socks.

Though senior department leadership was approachable, it felt that they were not empowered to advocate for the pharmacy's greater needs within the company. They also did not interact very often with the team, despite their offices being located within the department. The director was often off-site helping another location.

review_title: Great place to start a career
pros: Good culture, with good people in managerial roles. People genuinely cared about their jobs, and were very willing to teach others and share their expertise. Managers were personable, and most of the departments I worked with had a good culture. Benefits were great, and the work/life balance was pretty good.
cons: Pay is relatively low for low to middle management types. Hard to move up the ladder because you typically had to wait for someone above you to leave for you to get a promotion. Hard to move from one department to another without relative experience in that department. Very difficult to try and advance your career internally. Very rigid in HR policies, which sometimes made it feel as though we weren't being treated as humans (requiring PTO for doctors appointments, requiring doctors notes, putting signs on your desk if you were out to lunch or using the restroom, etc.)

review_title: Said the Cog in the Wheel: Is this it?
job_title: PCA and RN-BSN in Louisville, KY
pros: Competitive pay, good scheduling flexibility (including holidays and weekends), comforting level of job security within the region.  Good infection control implementations (when enforced). Also, the best computer charting system in the Louisville/Southern Indiana region.
cons:
Of the many healthcare organizations I have been apart of, Norton has the most big-corporation feel.  Small (sometimes seemingly petty) details related to policy often leaves employees feeling like voiceless replaceable machine parts.  And getting good surveys back often seems more important than fair patient treatment for all patients. For example: Patients with family present get better treatment and more attention out of fear that the family will send back bad surveys.  Employees are reprimanded more for not signing (legally insignificant) rounding sheets (for fear that family will see and be concerned) than they are for unsafe practices and shortcuts.  Having a voice about these issues is difficult in the environment because management is so little involved with staff and often lacking compassion for the struggle of staff related to staff shortages, old/unsafe supplies, etc.  Morale and often patient safety can be negatively impacted so that mgmt. meets some competitive goal with other managers from within their office.  So they just sit at their desks and bark new orders and policies often without obtaining staff insight or providing explanations.  The 'big bosses' only seem to show up on the unit when there is an inspection or a problem.    THEN the managers suddenly come out of their offices, and only to scare staff into being safer and faster than they have been expected (or even trained) to be before.  Then the entire staff becomes afraid and more voiceless than they were before.  I have witnessed many decent managers being regularly  fearful of losing their jobs.  I personally had 4-5 different bosses on the SAME UNIT (due to firing, quitting, and hiring) in my 6 years with Norton; imagine the fear and discomfort of subordinates with that sort of cycling leadership.  It is policy policy policy.  Survey survey survey.  And  fear of speaking up, because if you don't like it "there's the door." ...and that is IF there is anybody that cares to listen.  If you speak up and the wrong person hears it, you get the feeling there is a target on your back.  So at Norton, the big themes of the culture are: either say something positive or don't speak at all, and do what you can without stepping on any toes with the staff and supplies the big boss (who is never present) allots you.  Very 1984 Big Brother is wacthing.

The aforementioned culture of Norton leaves a person who came hoping to provide life-changing compassionate care for patients feeling like they are a cog in the wheel and wondering "Is this it?  Is this all I can accomplish in healthcare?"  There is a suffocating fear that looms in the air of units, leaving previously hopeful individuals choking on their suggestions for patient care.

 Also, having been a PCA and working my way up to RN, certain units at Norton treat their aides worse than any place I've ever seen (next to most nursing homes).  There is a ton of vertical abuse and the aides seem to have less voice than anyone.  It sometimes seems that there is no ceiling to the burden the hospital continues to place on these aides, leaving them feeling undervalued and defeated sooner than they've reached a year of service to the company.  This leads to aides constantly quitting these units, under-staffing, and resentment towards nurses from the aides that do stay.  In these situations communication and efficiency of the team is compromised.

review_title: Your manager will determine your experience at NH
pros:
*Very good benefits
* The opportunity to work with highly intelligent, capable people
cons:
*They tend to hire a particular type of person - if you don't fit the mold or aren't willing to mold yourself accordingly, you will be "encouraged" to leave
*Your experience will largely depend on who your manager is. Personally, my manager belittled me on a daily basis, to the point of tears every day. I know others who have had similar experiences. But on the flip side, I also know several people who have great managers and love their jobs.

pros: For the most part Norton Healthcare is a wonderful place to work. Many opportunities to move up within the company if you desire.
cons: Staff who choose not to move up are sometimes treated like the "hired" help by staff.  The market adjustments seem to be given out unfairly.  The RN's seem to get them more often then the rest of the staff, in 16 years I have received 1 market adjustment.

review_title: Great place to work - but only if you are clinical
job_title: Human Resources Manager in Louisville, KY
pros:
- great work life balance
- workload fairly minimal for ancillary departments 
- pay is decent, benefits are decent compared only to other healthcare organizations
cons:
- senior leadership tends to over promise and act without verifying that something is doable
- people who are long term basically have to kill someone in order to get let go, meaning there are some very toxic employees that will not be let go

review_title: Used to be great, now it is too political.
pros: Very flexible work to life balance.
cons: IT management tends to chase a lot of squirrels.  If an executive somewhere in the company wants something done.  IT management will just order the employees do it, without considering the implications.

pros: Good company to work for. Room to advance if you are younger.
cons: Hard to transfer into specialty areas if you are older or have many years of experience. I was told that it is cheaper for a unit to hire new grads and train them then it is to hire someone with many years of experience.

pros: Gained lots of experience. Good overall hours. Rarely had anyone watching over you as management was rarely there.
cons: Expected to do three jobs under 1 title. Little to no communication. Expected to do yearly physicals for their expensive insurance, but good luck getting off work to do it. High turnover rate because most employees are disgruntled. Too much drama and back stabbing for the little pay. Management doesn't listen or act.

pros: Friendly staff, respected physicians, respected healthcare system that is always striving to provide the latest and greatest in healthcare services.
cons: Constantly wanting more from nurses but giving them less. Mandatory call but no call-in pay. Flat rate shift diff. replaced percentage costing experienced nurses money. No cost of living pay increase in several years leaving PRN nurse pay stagnant. PRN required to work mandatory call above minimum requirement for status.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Louisville, KY
pros: Pay is highest in Louisville area for RN’s
cons: Zero respect to the bedside employee. Management creates an environment of scrutiny and ridicule between the two. Teamwork is not promoted between manager and nurse. It’s hard to feel secure in a job when you constantly feel minimized.

pros: Lots of opportunities to get involved with committees, great support from above for people that show motivation and desire to move the profession forward, great energy towards improving the quality of care, incentives to further education available, great coworkers, great teamwork
cons: sometimes changes are made that are not evidence based, high turnover of managers, expectations of RNs not up to par with other hospitals-need more accountability, need better communication with bedside RNs about coming changes/they may be more receptive if they are included in the planning process

Most employees change multiple locations before finding the right environment without this company if they decide to stay long term.

pros: The RN workload is not horrible and you are always supported by your team and charge nurses. I feel very supported as an employee here. You can't find a better work environment in the hospital system.
cons: I felt my orientation as a new graduate was not long enough. Turns out, i was more prepared than I thought though

pros: I really love my job and the people I work with. Everyone helps each other out and the shifts are pretty flexible.

pros: 3/12h shift and you are done! Plus you can pick extra shift anytime you want. The work with my school schedule perfectly fine and they are very flexible at the time to reschedule me. After 6 month they start paying for you school as well. Norton is a wonderful place to work and grow up. Norton treat their employees very well, makes you feel like family.
cons: None ( so far )

pros: I love most of my coworkers and that's about all i can think of. 20 word minimum fulfilled.
cons: very stressful environment, patient overload, some nurses don't think they should have to do small things like taking their patient water because that's "the aide's job"

pros: Honestly, there aren't a lot of pros anymore. When I first started over twenty years ago, it was great, but slowly it has become a horrible place to work.
cons: Where do I start? The benefits getting more expensive? The shift differential getting cut? The call pay getting reduced to "regular pay"? The more experienced employee getting looked over for the new employee just because they have a higher degree? The management not caring or even listening to employees? Feeling like the harder you work, the less the person next to you works? Company management not having any kind of "feel" for patient care? The corporate management cares nothing about anything other than the bottom line. The longer you have worked there, the worse you are treated. I could go on and on. If you are deciding between a career at Norton Healthcare or another corporation, take the other one. You will regret it if you choose Norton Healthcare.

cons: Culture needs work. Insconsistent from one facilitly to the next. No sense of cohesiveness, Too many program of the month approaches. Political climate difficult to navigate. Old boys club mentality. Management too far removed from day to day operations.

pros: Great advancement opportunities, and supportive workers. Anyone who are looking to get extra skills under their belt, and better work ethics, I recommend Norton.
cons: Needs more staffing in certain areas. Every company has cons somewhere. No company is 100% perfect. There is always room to grow.

pros: Do you miss the corporate america of the late 80's? Healthcare is the field for you! At Norton you can order your own supplies from office max and submit budget requests that go nowhere! Want to start a project? Norton Healthcare believes a central project planning department is a waste of money, so just start the project and find out if it's already been done when you present it to executives!
cons: Lack of diversity and talent  in executive roles create weak leadership with no interest in process improvement or advancing workplace environment to anything above simply tolerable.

review_title: A very positive experience for being with such a large company.
pros:
Immediate supervisor very professional and fair.
Good compensation.
Benefits were average.
cons:
Did not like the Paid TIme Off policy for using time off for vacations, holidays, etc.
Some of the people (co workers) at Norton were very rude and nasty and nothing was ever done about it.

pros: I've made some wonderful friends here.
cons: Cuts to salaries for senior nurses including shift differentials, weekend differentials, WOW pay, combining sick leave into flex time, higher premiums for insurance benefits with much higher deductibles, cuts to pay for performance, cuts to lunch discounts and many other benefits all the while our CEO's average salary is 3.2 million dollars compared to KentuckyOne CEO salary of under 1 million dollars (read article published in Courier Journal on Jan 30th 2015). I was once told, "nurses are a dime a dozen" and am often told "if you are unhappy, there's the door." This has been the philosophy of this company for many years and unfortunately I don't see it ever changing. There is one sided communication from the top down and so many layers of middle management that no one cares or listens. A professional nurses union might bring about some much needed change to this companies philosophy...but the last nurses who tried to organize were unjustly fired. My advise, keep looking for a different company who values loyalty, hard working employees, and the people who are the backbone to its company.

pros: The clinical care on the clinical side.
cons: Based on my experience, I would only work here on a clinical level at best. My job function was basically data entry with no advancement. I even asked to be trained in other things and nope. My first manager quit because of inappropriate sexualconduct with staff. My second Manager was good but the Director seemed was very cold in demeanor. The Director tried to come off as approachable but subordinates saw right through it. The Director made the job even more unbearable with her extreme micromanagement. Another thing is that you will not get paid holidays off even though offices will close. My dept was not clinical so being forced to used my vacation time was a major turn off. I was not told in my interview that I would need to use my vacation time to be paid on holidays. The whole time I was there, there was also an employee who created a hostile work environment with every employee in my dept. This employee (to my knowledge) received no corrective actions for their behavior. Also the employee liked to relay information to management about other employees and in turn management would call attention to issuses based on this employee. And I am pretty sure that the Supervisor was telling this employee confidential information about other employees. The Supervisor was borderline violating HIPAA viewing patient homes online according to their address. While I was there, several employees were just always unhappy feeling as if they were not being heard and it was strictly limited to the dept I was in. I am not sure if it was the people or the Director's rigid undertone. I can only speak for the dept I was in not the company as a whole.  Because of this, I just cannot commend Norton as a great place to work.
